result.execSummary:
The defendant Denzel T. Sanders was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Pay the costs of supervision.
Maintain employment at Whitehall Specialties.  Not to terminate such employment without his agent's prior approval.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means,  except through her agent or attorney, for third party contact for the sole purpose of facilitating the physical placement schedule of their children with the victim, or her residence.    Agent to approve the third party contact.  Defendant to comply with any family law orders.  Comply with mediation to obtain a visitation plan for children that limits contact with the victim.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known drug dealers or any known drug users or their residences.  Not to be present at any location where controlled substances are consumed or illegally sold.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Maintain housing that is suitable to his agent.  

Submit to a domestic violence or anger management assessment and comply with all recommendations from that assessment.  Defendant to attend and successfully complete the Jackson County Domestic Violence Court program.

timeConds.notes: EMP allowed according to jail rules.  Sentence to start on or before March 11, 2016 at 6 pm.  Any jail credit to be determined.  AMENDED 3/23/16.  Defendant is entitled to 3 days sentence credit.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes:
AMENDED 7/5/18.  Days of credit amended from 366 to 481.
Concurrent with: Jackson County cases 14CF99, 15CF118, 15CF54

superMiscConds.notes: If extended supervision is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if extended supervision is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of extended supervision.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known illegal drug users,  dealers, or go to known drug houses.

No contact with B.C. unless approved by probation agent and must be through a 3rd party in regards to children.

Must seek suitable housing which is approved by your agent.

Must submit to an anger management assessment and must comply with all recommendations for programming/treatment.  

Must submit to an AODA assessment and must comply with all recommendations for programming/treatment.

Defendant must execute all releases of information for assessments, counseling, treatment, to allow probation agent to verify compliance.

Must comply with any other recommendations of your probation agent.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: Same as prison sentence

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Corrected
Mailed out Victim Rights Information and Notification Card to victim

Defendant appears in custody from JASO with counsel SPD Carly Sebion.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  Attorney Sebion notes a couple corrections to the revocation summary.  A couple of the recommendations by the agent are amount above what's allowed.  

State asks the Court to accept the DOC's recommendation for sentencing.  Defense states this is a joint recommendation.  Attorney Sebion states he has substantial jail credit:  14CF118 - 478 days credit; 14CF99 - 364 days credit; 15CF97 - 366 days credit; and 15CF54 - 367 days credit.  Defendant makes statement to the Court.  

Court orders:
14CF99 - Count 1:  18 months prison, 6 months extended supervision
14CF118 - Count 1:  18 months prison, 6 months extended supervision
15CF54 - Count 1: 18 months prison, 6 months extended supervision
15CF97 - Count 1:  2 yrs prison , 3 years extended supervision.  All to be served concurrently.  Found not eligible for both programs.

Extended supervision conditions:  Must seek suitable housing approved by agent.  No contact with B.C. except approved by his agent and through a 3rd party in regards to children.  Must submit to an anger management assessment and must comply with any recommendations.  Must submit to an AODA assessment and must comply with all recommendations.  No alcohol or drugs unless prescribed.  No association with dealers, users, or known drug houses.  Must comply with any other recommendations of probation agent.  Must pay the court costs during term of extended supervision.  Sentence credit granted as stated by Attorney Sebion.
from DOC
forwarded to Judge Goodman.  JMM
Carly Sebion

DV Court.  Discussion on child visitation.
DNA submission form.

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, and with Attorneys Ritland and Betthauser.  Parties have the PSI.  No changes noted.  Victim is present.  Pictures and text messages provided to the defense today.  Attorney Betthauser argued against using them.  ADA Inlow made a statement.  Attorney Ritland also objects to their use.  Court referenced the Wisconsin Constitution.  Crime victim privileges stated by the court.  Victim has a right to make a statement.  Court will not allow the pictures or text messages to be used.  Victim's statement allowed to be read by victim/witness coordinator.  State recommended: probation 3 years.  No contact with the victim.  4 months jail.  DV programming. Attend Jackson County Domestic Violence court.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Attorney Ritland says it is a joint recommendation.  Allow the jail time with EMP.  Attorney Betthauser recommended probation also.  Joint recommendation for jail.  Allow the jail time with EMP.  Sentence credit to be determined.  Court advised the attorneys to submit a stipulation regarding jail credit.  Victim/witness coordinator read a statement written by the victim.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  

Court ordered: sentence withheld, 3 years probation, concurrent.  15CF97.  4 months jail, EMP allowed.  14CF99.  2 years probation, concurrent.  15CF54 2 years probation, concurrent.  14CF118, 100 day jail.  Stayed on the condition that he maintains employment.  2 years probation.  Concurrent.   Domestic violence assessment and programming.  Attend and successfully complete the Jackson County Domestic Violence Court program.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Complete an AODA assessment and follow through with any recommended treatment.
Absolutely no contact with victim or her residence except through his agent or attorney.  Agent to help facilitate 3rd party visitation with children.  Comply with any family law orders.  
Comply with mediation to obtain a visitation plan for children that limits contact with the victim.
Pay all court ordered financial obligations, supervision fees, and any other fees deemed appropriate.
Cooperate with any other assessment and treatment programming deemed appropriate by the Department of
Corrections.
Jail credit to be determined.  
Maintain employment, not to terminate without agent approval.  
Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.
Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion..  Not associate with dealers, users or where located.
Jail to start on or before March 11, 2016 at 6 pm.

of Order for PSI mailed to defendant.  RTS.  Not deliverable as addressed.  UTF

Defendant Denzel T. Sanders in court with attorney James Ritland regarding 14CF99, 14CF118 & 14CF196 and Charles D Betthauser regarding 15CF54 & 15CF97.  Gerald R. Fox appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Victim notification complied with. No restitution due at this time. Defendant plead no contest to Ct. 1 in 14CF99; amended Ct. 1 in 15CF54; and Ct. 1 in 15CF97. Defendant plead guilty to Ct. 1 in 14CF118. Court advised defendant of the charge in each of the cases and potential penalties. Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, elements and constitution rights. Defendant understood. Defense stipulated to a factual basis for the plea. Court found the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived his constitutional rights and entered his plea. Court found a factual basis exists. Court accepts defendant's plea of no contest to Ct. 1 in 14CF99; amended Ct. 1 in 15CF54; and Ct. 1 in 15CF97 and guilty plea to Ct. 1 in 14CF118. Court ordered Ct. 2 in 14CF99, Ct. 2 in 14CF118, Ct. 1 in 14CF196, Ct. 2 in 15CF54 and Cts. 2 and 3 in 15CF97 dismissed but read-in. Pre-sentence investigation shall be due in 60 days and available to the parties 10 days before sentencing. Bond conditions continue.  Court makes finding of guilty on all charges as pled.
